title-group.article-title: Nonlinear vibration of structural deterioration in reinforced concrete columns: experimental and theoretical investigation

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Architectural Engineering, Yung Ta Institute of Technology, Taiwan
2Department of Occupational Safety, Health/Institute of Occupational Safety and Disaster Prevention, Chia Nan University of Pharmacy and Science, Taiwan
3Department and Graduate School of Computer Science, National Pingtung University of Education, Taiwan
4Global Earth Observation and Data Analysis Center (GEODAC), National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan
5Department of information Management, National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology, Kaohsiung, Taiwan
6Department of Architecture, National Cheng-Kung University, Taiwan

author-notes.corresp: Chen-Yuan Chen, Department and Graduate School of Computer Science, National Pingtung University of Education, No. 4–18, Ming Shen Rd., Pingtung 90003, Taiwan Email: cyc@mail.npue.edu.tw

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An intelligence testing investigation was conducted to investigate the effect of a hoop arrangement on the degradation behavior of reinforced concrete columns. The test program included 16 full-scale tests of reinforced concrete columns with different hoop arrangements. The columns were subjected to constant axial compression, and incrementally increasing lateral force reversals or monotonies. The parameters of the specimens included the following: concrete compressive stress fc’, hoop space, hoop type, axial loading and length of the columns. Test results indicate that the ultimate strength of columns with closed type hoops was not significantly different from that with conventional hoops. However the strength increased about 10% when the concrete compressive stress fc’ was less than 20.58 mpa. The method presented in the paper is better than that used in previous reports. This model can be used to predict structural deterioration and prevent damage in building design.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Many structural failures of concrete structures during recent earthquakes can be attributed to poor column behavior in the ultimate structural failure range. The problem of how to enhance the strength of columns to minimize loss of life and property is an important one.

Deterioration prediction methods have already been proposed for the maintenance of rotating equipment (Goto et al., 2008). For example, the hierarchical neural network (HNN) has been adapted to calculate compensation for deterioration of a milling system (Abe et al., 2007). This study looks at the behavior of concrete columns under stress. Concrete confined in columns has stress-strain characteristics that are distinctly different from those of plain concrete. The strength of concrete is difficult to determine theoretically because of the nonlinear and non-homogeneous characteristics of the material and the multi-axial state of the stress. Testing data are often used to develop empirical and semi-empirical approaches (Ozeebe and Saateioglu, 1987). Artificial intelligence and numerical computations are common methodologies for various practical issues (Gao et al., 2008; Grispim et al., 2008; Liu et al., 2008; Li et al., 2008; Su et al., 2008; Tsai et al., 2008; Yang et al., 2008; Yeh et al., 2008; Lei and Chien, 2009; Lin et al., 2009; Tsai and Chen, 2009; Lin and Chen, 2010).

Actually, the stress-strain characteristics of confined concrete have been the subject of much study (Sheikh and Uzumeri, 1982; Kent and Park, 1971). New types of hoops are under development to enhance columnar strength (Shibata et al., 1992; Mo and Wang, 2000). However, ACI-codes (American Concrete Institute) do not specify hoop types, just the need of minimum spacing (American Concrete Institute, 2002). The motivation for this study then, is to determine the effect of the ultimate strength and the feasibility of reinforcing columns with closed type hoops. Practical tests are performed to evaluate the viability for use in real systems. The test results conducted under simulated seismic loading are compared with the value calculated following the ACI-code method. The modified Kent and Park theory results show the confined concrete columns to be more effective. Also, the ultimate strength of the reinforced concrete (RC) column does increase.

sec.title: 2. Specimens and testing program
sec.p:
The specimens represent a portion of a first-story column between the foundation and the inflection point, located on the first floor of a five-story building. The geometry of the specimen is illustrated in Figure1. The properties of the test specimens are summarized inTable 1. The longitudinal reinforcement arrangement was identical for all columns. Twelve #5 (∮=15.9mm) deformed bars were symmetrically placed inside the perimeter ties. Two types of hoop were used in the construction of the specimen. The conventional hoop arrangement has one square peripheral hoop and two pairs of rectilinear internal ties, each with one 135o hook anchor and another 90o hook anchor. The closed type hoop has only one rectilinear bar but many over-lapping hoops, as shown inFigure 2. The test specimens had the same cross-sectional dimensions, 40 cm × 40 cm, but a height of L = 135 cm for the flexural failure type test, and L = 50 cm and 40 cm for the shear failure type test. The main variables were the configuration of the hoops, the ratio of transverse reinforcement and the level of axial loading. Short column tests were under-taken after the other column tests with the same specimens but fixed to the column web in subject length (40 cm or 50 cm). Figure 1.
Geometric detail of the test specimen and gages.
Figure 2.
Closed type hoop.
Table 1.
Column size, reinforcement arrangement and test results
Specimen Column size (cm) Hoop spacing (cm) fc’(mpa) fy(mpa) Axial load (kN) Lateral load Pu (kN) Drift Δ(mm)
CTM1 135 H1 23.52 411.6 329.28 152.88 38.76
CTM2 135 H2 17.64 411.6 329.28 123.38 69.60
CCM1 135 H1 20.48 411.6 329.28 128.87 68.68
CCM2 135 H2 17.64 411.6 329.28 130.34 58.90
CTR1 135 H3 23.52 411.6 588.00 191.98 39.70
CTR2 135 H4 25.84 411.6 490.00 187.47 32.22
CCR1 135 H3 23.52 411.6 329.28 151.21 110.00
CCR2 135 H4 23.52 411.6 588.00 183.55 56.60
STM1 50 H1 23.52 411.6 329.28 300.76 38.49
STM2 50 H2 17.64 411.6 329.28 273.03 47.25
SCM1 50 H1 20.48 411.6 329.28 362.89 56.88
SCM2 50 H2 17.64 411.6 329.28 296.45 57.60
STR1 40 H3 23.52 411.6 588.00 485.59 28.91
STR2 40 H4 25.84 411.6 588.00 501.47 40.28
SCR1 40 H3 23.52 411.6 588.00 453.84 31.41
SCR2 40 H4 23.52 411.6 588.00 481.08 15.06
Note: a. The 1st word of specimen name C: common column; S: short column, the 2nd word T: Hoop and tie in conventional type; C: closed type hoop and tie, the 3rd word M (or R): lateral loading in monotonic type (repeat cyclic loading), and the 4th word: number of specimen.
b . Hoop spacing H1:h = 10 cm; H2:1/2 h = 15 cm, 1/4 h = 10 cm; H3:h = 15 cm; and H4:1/2 h = 25 cm, 1/4 h = 15 cm

As shown in Figure 3, different specimens were arranged with different hoop spacing for testing of RC column designs. Table 1 shows the different characteristics of the specimens. Figure 3.
Hoop arrangement showing uniform distribution and different spacing on the column.

sec.title: 3. Instrumentation setup and loading sequence
sec.p: Four calibrated load cells, two for lateral loading and two for axial loading, were used to monitor and record applied lateral forces and axial loading. The corresponding relative drift between the top and bottom of the column was measured by two pairs of 50 mm dial gauges. Seven potentiometers were mounted on each side of the column parallel to the loading direction to measure vertical, horizontal, and diagonal deformations of the specimen, and to evaluate the shear and flexural deformation modes. Electric resistance strain gauges were attached on the surfaces of the longitudinal reinforcing bars about 10 cm from the base top.

A schematic drawing of the test setup is shown in Figure 4. These serious numbers are pointed out in the relative section in this test as: 1) Connected ear of test frame, 2) Actuator, 3) Extension rod of actuator, 4) Sensor of test record, 5) Connector between test cap and actuator, 6) Steel test cap, 7) Lateral fixed system, 8) Spring for hanging actuator, 9) Fixed rod on base of specimen, 10) Normal loading rod, 11) Specimen. The specimen was mounted vertically with the bottom of the RC foundation resting on a steel foundation. The end of the column was loaded using a hydraulic jack and controlled to provide a constantaxial force varying from 329.28 kN to 588 kN (i.e., about 0.1 fc’Ag to 0.2 fc’Ag). The column was subjected to reverse cyclic loading by an actuator that was horizontally mounted on a steel rigid frame. The actuator had a capacity of 500 kN and was capable ofmoving the column 200 mm in both positive and negative directions. Each specimen was equipped with loaded cells, displacement transducers, creep bond gauges and strain gauges to monitor the behavior during testing. Also, the cracking in the specimens during testing was mapped after each step. Figure 4.
Instrumental test setup.

The specimens were tested under controlled force. After the constant axial loading reached 329.28 kN, 490 kN or 588 kN, horizontal loading was monotonically increased for specimens CTM, CCM, STM and SCM. On specimens CTR, CCR, STR and SCR, the horizontal force after the constant axial loading was increased by repeat cyclic loading. The horizontal force to which the specimens were subjected was increased by 50 kN every cycle after the first three cycles with 30 kN. The loading routine, shown in Figure 5, consists of cycles with the column back and forward under seismic loading. Figure 5.
Loading history of the specimen.

sec.title: 4. Testing results
sec.p:
The P-Δ relations obtained from the test are shown in Figures 6 to 9, where P represents the lateral force applied to the specimen and Δ is the lateral drift at the top of the column. From the P-Δ curves in these figures, it can be seen that most specimens exhibited good strength during testing. Specimens failed by concrete rupturing in the final step. Figure 6.
Curve showing test results under monotonic loading of 135 cm columns.

sec.title: 4.1. Theoretical value following the ACI-code method
sec.p: The ultimate strength of a columnar section which is subject to axial loading was calculated with the ACI-code method. The section strain compatibility condition and force equilibrium considered condition were calculated to determine the ultimate bending moment of the column per section area as follows: (1)Cc=0.85*fc'*0.85*c*w; (2)Cs=>(ɛsc*Es-0.85*fc'>)*Asc≤>(fy-0.85*fc'>)*Asc (3)Ts1=ɛ1*As1*Es≤fy*As1 (4)Ts2=ɛ2*As2*Es≤fy*As2 (5)Ts3=ɛ3*As3*Es≤fy*As3 Force equilibrium requires (6)Cc+Cs=N+Ts1+Ts2+Ts3

sec.title: 4.2. Theoretical value calculated following the modified Kent and Park theory
sec.p: In this model, the strength and ductility of the concrete core are enhanced by the confinement provided by the transverse hoops. The model consists of an ascending parabolic branch and a descending straight branch. The concrete strength kfc’ is reached at a strain of 0.002 k; k is defined in Equation (9).
The stress-strain relationship is

Table.2 shows the test results. The values are calculated following the ACI-code, using modified Kent and Park model and the ratio value of each other. The theoretical ultimate strength of each specimen was calculated following the modified Kent and Park theory and the ACI-code method for relative values, as shown by the lines in Figures 10 to 12. The test results for the specimens are also compared with these. Table 2.
Comparison of calculated and test results

sec.title: 5. Discussion
sec.p:
Figure 6 reveals that the ultimate strength of the specimen is related to the compressive strength fc’ of the concrete, but the ductility is not absolutely the same. With the same parameter conditions, the ultimate strength of CCM2 is higher than that of CTM2. This reveals that the closed hoop construction enhances the ultimate strength of the column more than does the conventional hoop construction. The same result is obtained for the short column test as shown in Figure7. The ultimate strength of SCM2 is better than that of STM2. The repeat cyclic loading tests results for both the normal column and the short columns are shown in Figures 8 and 9, respectively. Figures 10 to 12 reveal the relation of test results and lines from ACI-code method and modified Kent and Park theory that has higher values than the ACI-code method’s. The results reveal that the ultimate strength of columns with the closed type hoops will be better than conventional hoops whenthe compressive stress of the concrete is fc’ less than 20.58 mpa. In contrast, the ultimate strength of columns with the closed type hoops is not absolutely better than that of columns with conventional hoops. The ultimate strength of CTR1 with less hoop spacing is better than that of CCR2, as shown in Figure 10. The results of a comparison of CTM1 to CCR1, and STR1 to SCR2 (in Figure 12) are similar. Meanwhile, the ultimate strength shows an increase for specimens CTR1 and CCR2. CTR2 has larger axial loading than CTM1 or CCR1, as shown in Figure 10. However, a comparison of the test results and Kent and Park calculation results shows that the test results are more significant, with even better ratio values, exceeding 1.0 to 1.4. See Figure 13 and Table 2. The comparison affirms the efficiency of the confined concrete with closed hoop configuration. Figure 7.
Curve showing test results under monotonic loading of short columns (50 cm).
Figure 8.
Curve showing CTR2 test results under repeat cyclic loading.
Figure 9.
Curve showing SCR2 test results under repeat cyclic loading.
Figure 10.
Curve showing test results distribution obtained following Kent and Park’s confined concrete theory for L = 135 cm columns.
Figure 11.
Curve showing test results distribution obtained following Kent and Park’s confined concrete theory for L = 50 cm columns. Figure 12.
Curve showing test results distribution obtained following Kent and Park’s confined concrete theory for L = 40 cm columns.
Figure 13.
Comparison of test results to results obtained following Kent and Park’s confined concrete theory.

sec.title: 6. Summary and conclusions
sec.p: According to the ACI-code, the ultimate strength of a column is considered for the material strength of concrete and the steel. The Kent and Park theory only enhanced the hoop effect of an element besides the material strength. These formulas were used to calculate the result in each specimen. The comparisons in the present study are drawn for the superiority of the related results.

The effects of the closed hoops where the threshold value of fc' is 20.58 mpa can be comprehended from the results shown in Figures 10 to 13. The reasons are as follows. The concrete strength is normally used 20.58 mpa in construction that it is to be figured out as a nominate value. Besides, the hoop is limited in ultimate performance when the concrete strength is lower than 20.58 mpa, such as the results of CTM2, CCM1, CCM2, STM2, SCM2, seen in Table 2. Lastly, in this study, the efficiency of an frame element will be revealed from this study, in the case when concrete strength is higher than 20.58 mpa.

The seismic performance of a new configuration for transverse reinforcement is tested. The experimental results show that the new closed type of configuration provides comparable or improved seismic performance to the configuration normally used in construction. However, this combination takes more time and it is difficult to assemble on site. Some conclusions are listed as follows:
The ultimate strength of columns with a closed type hoop construction is better than that with conventional hoops when the concrete compressive stress fc’ is less than 20.58 mpa. by about 10%.
The effect of closed hoops on the ultimate strength of short columns when the compressive strength exceeds 20.58 mpa (=3000 psi) is not clear.
Spacing of the hoops has a bigger effect on the ultimate strength of the column than the type of hoop for the condition where fc’ is greater than 20.58 mpa.
Axial loading obviously affects the ultimate strength of confined concrete columns.
The closed hoop configuration is better for confined concrete.

There has been increasing interest in structural stability and its applications (Omurlu et al., 2008; Tusset et al., 2009; Baños et al., 2010; Fu et al., 2010; Fang and Xu, 2010; Jayaswal et al., 2010; Shih et al., 2010a,b). Analytical models with artificial intelligence are common methodologies for various practical issues (Hsiao et al., 2005a,b,c,d; Hsieh et al., 2006; Liu et al., 2010; Morshed and Kazemi, 2005; Bhattacharya et al., 2007; Koike et al., 2007; Almutairi and Zribi, 2009; Amini and Vahdani, 2009; Chen, 2010a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,i,j, 2011a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,i,j,k,l,m.n, 2012a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,i; Metin and Guclu, 2011; Soundarrajan and Sumathi, 2011). Although there has been increased interest in dynamic analysis and optimization algorithms in the system, they are currently used only in numerical experiments. This study shown the effect of a single element, when the concrete is considered with hoop effect. The evidence of the influence was shown in Table 2. That is a good agreement in promoting an element strength in structure. To predict an element behavior, even a structure under lateral forth or earthquake, these results of this study will be benefit with related fields.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors are grateful for the support of their funding body. The authors are also most grateful for the kind assistance of Professor Ali Nayfeh, Editor of JVC, and for the constructive suggestions from the anonymous reviewers, all of which has led to the making of several corrections and have greatly aided us to improve the presentation of this paper.
